Prince!
You should know:
Do not be attached to delusion and intoxication. In this perilous situation, diligently seek liberation.
As the Buddha has said:
If one is free from delusion and intoxication, this person is greatly courageous.
Pure, without defilement, towards all sentient beings,

At that time, the Buddha told the Venerable Guardian of the Nation:
After the Heavenly Son Pure Light spoke these verses, Prince Fu Guang reached the age of ten, his wisdom was clear and penetrating, yet he was without idle speculation.

In the world, they do not become attached to gardens, forests, flowers, ponds, flowing springs, bathing pools, singing, dancing, or music, and even the country, cities, palaces, elephants, horses, carriages, gold, silver, wealth, and treasures, and all desired things, they all completely avoid.
With single-minded thought, they contemplate:
'My body is illusory, a temporary combination of the four elements, without any solidity. The great earth and the gods are not ultimate.

The prince, seeing what was asked, bowed his head and said to the father-king:
Falling into sentient beings, bound to living beings,
Increasing great faults, forever dwelling in samsara,
Without any escape.
I now seek liberation, give rise to the mind of great enlightenment, and distance myself from all defilements.
The bodies of all women are the basis of many evils and impurities,
I regard them as enemies.
Wandering in birth and death, binding all sentient beings,
Always dwelling on a great dangerous path.
The skin covering impurities, blood, flesh, bones, and marrow,
Intestines, stomach, large and small intestines, feces, tears, snot, saliva, and so forth,
In this way, this filthy and evil body, how can it be made lovable?
It is like a poisonous tree, with flowers that are loved by many,
But when the flowers are picked, the poison enters the body, and one unknowingly loses one's life.
The country, city, and palace, music, singing and dancing,
In the end, are not solid, like a dream, like an illusion.
It is also like the trees in spring, lush and fragrant with leaves,

Women and wealth are also like this, not lasting for long.
The mind is confused and crazy, always sinking in the ocean of desire,
Fighting and giving rise to hatred, mutually engaging in killing.

The bodhisattvas, great wise ones, their body and mind always tranquil,

I am not attached to foolish delusion, far removed from falsehood,
Form, sound, and the five desires of the senses are not the realm of the bodhisattvas.
When blessings are exhausted, blessings are born; when karma is exhausted, karma is born again,

The four elements are not solid, like an empty village.

Relying on true liberation, always operating the wondrous Dharma boat,
Liberating from the three existences.
Those bound are liberated, those suffering are made secure,
The blind are given sight, the poor are given precious wealth,
All are made to leave behind sorrow and suffering.
Drying up the river of craving, illuminating the dark path,
Broadly spreading clouds and thunder, showering down the rain of sweet dew,
Removing heat and attaining coolness, accomplishing the highest wisdom.

What person, harboring kindness and patience, would want to make enemies?
What person, possessing wisdom, would be afraid to see the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha?
What person, having eyes, would enter a dangerous path?
What person, having attained enlightenment, would want to create distraction?
Such a wise person will certainly not follow the wrong path.
Throwing oneself into the great ocean, in these five desires and dust,

And all the retinue, go to the deep mountains,
Cultivate pure practices, and aspire to seek the unsurpassed path.
